Keywords Paraclinoid aneurysm,Distal dural ring,High-resolution MR imaging Purpose: Stent-assisted coiling of acutely ruptured wide-necked intracranial aneurysms is controversial because of concerns about the risk of using antiplatelet therapy. Dual microcatheter technique is an alternative in these aneurysms and it does not require antiplatelet therapy. In this study we assess the safety and long-term efficacy of this technique for the treatment of acutely ruptured wide-necked aneurysms. Methods: A retrospective review of 49 patients with ruptured widenecked intracranial aneurysms treated with dual microcatheter technique was done. The angiographic results, treatment-related complications, and clinical outcome were documented. Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) was used for clinical outcome. Angiographic follow-up using digital subtraction angiography or magnetic resonance angiography was available in 30 patients at a mean of 18.2 months. Both postembolization and follow-up angiograms were graded on a 3-point Raymond scale. Aneurysms were classified as stable, improved, or recanalized based on the follow-up 7%) aneurysms demonstrated recanalization. Four aneurysms with recanalization were retreated endovascularly; there was one aneurysm of re-rupture in follow-up, which was incompletely packed initially. Conclusion: Dual microcatheter technique is safe and effective for coil embolization of acutely ruptured wide-necked intracranial aneurysms with a low treatment-related complication, morbidity, and mortality rate. However, the high rate of postembolization incomplete occlusion and recanalization remains the main challenge. More and longer term angiographic follow-up information is needed to better define the durability of treatment.Keywords Wide-necked aneurysms,Subarachnoid hemorrhage,Dual-microcatheter technique ECO8:05 TREATMENT OF RUPTURED BLOOD-BLISTER-LIKE ANEURYSMS IN THE SUBACUTE PHASE: CLINICAL AND ANGIOGRAPHIC OUTCOME F Di Maria 1 , F Clarencon 1 , J Gabrieli 1 , A Nouet 1 , J Chiras 1 , N Sourour 1 Groupe Hospitalier Pitié-Salpêtrière Charles Foix, Paris, FRANCE

TABREF55.text: Keywords EV TREATMENT ANEURYSM,BIFURCATION CEREBRAL ANEURYSM,WEB SL DEVICE ECO8:07 FLOW DIVERTER STENTS FOR THE TREATMENT OF ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY ANEURYSMS: SAFETY-EFFICACY PROFILE F Clarencon 1 , F Di Maria 1 , J Gabrieli 1 , E Shotar 1 , C Zeghal 1 , A Nouet 1 , J Chiras 1 , N Sourour 1Groupe Hospitalier Pitié-Salpêtrière Charles Foix, Paris, FRANCE Purpose: Flow diverter stents (FDSs) are increasingly used for the treatment of intracranial aneurysms. Initially developed for the management of giant and large aneurysms, their indications have progressively enlarged. The purpose of our study was to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of FDSs for the treatment of anterior cerebral artery (ACA) aneurysms. Methods: Among the 94 consecutive patients treated for 100 intracranial aneurysms by means of FDSs in our institution from October 2010 to January 2015, 8 aneurysms (8%) in 7 patients were located on the ACA. Three aneurysms were located on the A1 segment, 3 aneurysms on the anterior communicating artery and 2 on the A3 segment. In 3 cases, FDS was used for angiographic recurrence after coiling. Five patients were treated with a Pipeline Embolization Device, 1 with a Neuroendograft and a last one with a Silk FDS. Result: Treatment was feasible in all cases. No technical difficulty was reported. No acute or delayed clinical complication was recorded. Modified Rankin Scale was 0 for 6 patients and 1 for one patient. Mean angiographic follow-up was 10.4±4.2 months (range 6-15). Total exclusion was observed in 5 cases (71.4%) and neck remnant in 2 (28.6%) cases. One patient refused to undergo a control angiography. Conclusion: Our series shows the safety and efficacy of FDSs for the treatment of ACA aneurysms. Keywords Anterior cerebral artery,flow diversion,aneurysmECO8:08 REPORT OF THREE CASES WITH THE PULSERIDER FOR THE TREATMENT OF BIFURCATION ANEURYSMS -INITIAL EXPERIENCE OF THE TREVISO NEURORADIOLOGY DEPARTMENTA Stafa 1 , M Ronzon 1 , S Curtolo 1 , F Di Paola 1 Neuroradiology Dpt. of Ca'Foncello Regional Hospital, Treviso, ITALY Purpose: The PulseRider is a new device recentley introduced for use in the treatment of aneurysms of bifurcations, with a large neck or with an unsuitable dome/neck ratio. We present the initial results of the first three cases treated in the Neuroradiology Department of Treviso Ca' Foncello Hospital employing the PulseRider device. Methods: One male with a basilar tip aneurysm and 2 females with a MCA bifurcation aneurysm were preselected in a prospective way. They were pretreated with dual antiplatelet therapy and an appropriately sized PulseRider device was deployed across the neck of the aneurysm, in general anesthesia. A microcatheter was then navigated over a 0.014 microwire through the device into the aneurysm. Result: Complete occlusion of the aneurysm with coils was achieved in all cases without intraprocedural complications. Conclusion: In our initial experience PulseRider seems to be safe and effective as an aditional tool for the treatment of bifurcation aneurysms and it represents a useful technical element to be considered in specific cases. Keywords PulseRider,Unruptured aneurysms,wide neck aneurysms coiling ECO8:09 KISSING-Y STENTING FOR ENDOVASCULAR TREATMENT OF COMPLEX WIDE-NECKED BIFURCATION ANEURYSMS USING ACANDIS® ACCLINO® STENTS: RESULTS AND LITERATURE REVIEW F Brassel 1 , K Melber 1 , M Schlunz-Hendann 1 , D Meila 1,2

TABREF56.text: Purpose: To highlight the various techniques to treat the cavernous segment aneurysm of ICA depending on its size, shape and clinical presentation. Methods: 70 patients were included in this study during interval of 5 years from January 2011 to December 2014. 40 males and 30 females were included, as mean age 36 years. Prior to neuro-intervention procedure on all patients diagnostic cerebral DSA were performed on Siemen Artis Z Biplane. Clinically patients were presented with headache, pressure symptoms with bleed and without bleed. Depending on the location, direction & shape of the aneurysms different types of endovascular techniques were employed ranging from ballooning, sacrificing ICA, coiling, coiling with stenting/ flow diverters. All procedures were performed under GA except few cases. Result: Out of all 70 patients only one patient developed transient ischemia. No other significant complication were noted.Conclusion: According to our experience of 70 cases of cavernous segment aneurysm, neuro endovascular intervention appears the preferred and safest choice of treatment with minimal complications. Selection of the neuro endovascular technique depends on the size, shape, direction and location of aneurysm along the wall of ICA. Clinical outcomes were retrospectively collected at discharge and at follow-up and then classified by using the modified Rankin Scale of Disability. Result: Among 527 aneurysms, 491 presented complete blood-flow exclusion; 36 were suspended: 13 coils protrusions, 18 impossible catheterization due to vascular tortuosity, 4 severe vasospasms 1 wasn't performed because of anti-aggregation-therapy poor response. Among SAH patients, 12 haemorrhages and 17 thrombosis, mainly caused by vasospasm; 24 vasospasms/thrombosis 5 haemorragies occurred. In the post-operative period we observed 59 mild and 6 severe ischemias; 12 mild and 3 severe haemorrhagies occurred. Out of 460, we analysed clinical data from 295 patients: 89 patients were lost at follow-up and 76 died: 39 patients because of SAH-sequelae, 31 died because of reasons such as age, cardiopulmonary diseases or cancer. 41 out of 527 recurrent aneurysms were retreated (4 second retreatment). 30 were large/giant and irregular in shape (20 previously coiled, 10 embolized with stent and coils) Conclusion: Our experience demonstrates that endovascular treatments of intracranial aneurysms has an acceptable safety profile with low rates of technical failure and retreatment. Bravo-Rodriguez 1 , I.Purpose: To assess the results of intra-arterial treatment in patients with acute ischemic stroke after the implementation of a clinical practice protocol in our center. Methods: Retrospective study including all patients with acute ischemic stroke due to occlusion of large vessels in the anterior circulation treated in our hospital between January 2010 and December 2014. Zaccagna 1 , B. Ganeshan 2 , M. Rengo 1 , M. Arca 1 , I. Carbone 1 , L. Menezes 2 Sapienza Università di Roma, Rome, ITALY, 2 University College of London, London, UNITED KINGDOM Purpose: To evaluate the potential role of CT texture as a marker of plaque vulnerability.Methods: From a patient population of 341 patients with cardiovascular risk factors we identify 12 patients (7 male; age 72±10.37 yrs) with carotid atherosclerosis and a subsequent history of Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or Stroke.These were age and sex matched with 12 control cases (7 male; age 71.3±9.86 yrs) with asymptomatic carotid atherosclerosis (follow-up time 103.58±9.2 months). Carotid artery stenosis and plaque composition (lipid, calcified or mixed) were determined. Texture analysis was performed using a commercially available software package (TexRAD, Somerset, UK) by a single operator blinded to clinical data. TexRAD uses a filtration-histogram based texture analysis technique to extract pixel size based (fine, medium, coarse) features and quantified histogram parameters including Kurtosis (K), skewness (S) and normalized standard-deviation (SDn). A single axial slice was selected to best represent the carotid bifurcation for each side and a region of interest (ROI) was manually delineated in order to fully enclose the artery. Statistical analysis was performed using X2, t-test and Mann-Whitney test as appropriate. Result: Stenosis degree was greater in the right internal carotid artery of patients with TIA (41±35 vs 6±12; p=0.006), however no statistically significant differences were found between the two groups for stenosis degree in left internal carotid artery (p=0.746) and plaque composition (p=0.485 and p=0.705). There was a statistically significant difference in Skewness between symptomatic and asymptomatic patients for post filtration at the fine and medium texture level (p=0.009 for spatial scaling factor (SSF) =2mm; p<0.001 for SSF=3mm and p=0.003 for SSF=4mm). SDn was statistically significant different between symptomatic and asymptomatic patients for spatial scaling factor =2mm (p=0.033). Conclusion: CT texture identified vulnerable plaque in Stroke and TIA, whereas degree of stenosis and plaque composition did not. CT texture may have the potential to act as a new means of risk stratification in patients with carotid atherosclerosis.TEXTURE ANALISIS,CAROTID ARTERY,plaque vulnerability EPO:129 ACCURACY OF GADOTERIDOL ENHANCED MR-ANGIOGRAPHY IN THE EVALUATION OF CAROTID ARTERY STENOSISTHE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROSPECTIVELY EVALUATE THE ACCURACY OF MR ANGIOGRAPHY (MRA) IN EVALUATING CAROTID ARTERY STENOSIS, COMPARING THE DIAGNOSTIC PERFORMANCE OF GADOTERIDOL ENHANCED MRA WITH GADOBUTROL ENHANCED MRA. Mondino National Neurological Institute, Neurology, Pavia, ITALYPurpose: To identify and localize (acute) punctuate hippocampal lesions after transitory global amnesia is important to confirm the diagnosis. The detection rate of such lesions has been reported as dependent by several DWI parameters. In this retrospective case series of 20 consecutive patients studied within four days, we found an high detection rate of hippocampal and (one) parahippocampal punctuate lesions by applying a 3T MRI protocol with long TE (150 ms) DWI. In a subsample of patients studied also with standard short TE (98ms) DWI, we confirm the higher sensitivity of long TE DWI. Methods: 20 patients admitted to our Neurological Institute and fitting diagnostic criteria for transient global amnesia(Caplan 1985, Hodges  1990 were consecutively studied by 3T MRI within four days from symptoms. By a Siemens Skyra 3T scanner with 32 channel phase array headcoil, the following optimized MRI protocol was acquired in every patients: axial DWI, volumetric sagittal FLAIR, high resolution coronal T2. Result: 18/20 patients presented DWI punctuate hyperintensities within mesiotemporal lobes, all in hippocampi but one patient, with a lesion within the deep white matter close to left hippocampus. In 4 patients studied with boh DWI sequences, the lesion visibility was always better on DWI with the long TE (150ms) compared to DWI with short TE (98ms). Spenger 1 , F. Reininghaus 1 , T. Hauer 1 , J. Harlap 1 , V.E. Gomes Gouveia 1 , E. Westman 2Purpose: Hippocampal volume loss is an established radiological biomarker for Alzheimer's disease (AD). However, it can be difficult to decide by visual inspection whether the hippocampal volume is in the normal range or not, in particular since hippocampal volume changes with age. Hence, we have implemented a fully automated, web based system, "appMRI Hippocampus Volume analyser" (appMRI HVA) to calculate the hippocampal volume quantitatively for clinical use. The purpose of this work was to validate the percentile ranking chart of appMRI HVA. Methods: The percentile ranking chart, showing total hippocampal volume as function of age, was calculated using magnetic resonance images (MRI) of 103 control subjects of the AddNeuroMed study. Total hippocampal volume was assessed using appMRI HVA (hipp.appmri.com). The total hippocampal volumes of 137 AD-and 156 control-subjects from the ADNI study were compared to the 5% percentile curve and true positive, false positive, true negative, and false negative numbers assessed and the sensitivity and specificity calculated using MedCalc statistical software. Result: Out of 156 control subjects, 147 were above and 9 below the 5th percentile, validating position and slope of the percentile curve. True positive number was 86, false positive number was 51, true negative number was 147 and false negative number was 9. Hence, the sensitivity and specificity was 90.5% and 74.2% respectively. Conclusion: The fact that 5.7 % of the control subjects of the ADNI cohort was below the 5% percentile supports the comparability of the ADNI and AddNeuroMed datasets and validates the percentile chart.Hippocampal volume,Alzheimer's disease,Software EPO:133 NEUROIMAGING OF PATHOLOGICALLY PROVED TYPICAL AND ATYPICAL PROGRESSIVE SUPRANUCLEAR PALSY: DIAGNOSTIC CHALLENGES K. Sakurai 1 , A.M Tokumaru 2 , K Ito 2 , K Shimoji 2 , S Murayama 3 , S Morimoto 3 , M Shimohira 1 , Y Ozawa 1 , M Nakagawa 1 , Y Shibamoto 1 Department of Radiology, Nagoya City University Graduate School of Medical Sciences, Nagoya, JAPAN, 2 Department of Diagnostic Radiology, Tokyo Metropolitan Medical Center of Gerontology, Itabashi-ku, JAPAN, 3 Department of Neurology, Tokyo Metropolitan Geriatric Hospital, Tokyo, JAPANPurpose: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by supranuclear palsy, postural instability, and cognitive impairment. Recently, it has been reported that PSP comprises not only typical cases (i.e., Richardson's syndrome) but also various clinical subtypes with atypical symptoms such as levodopa-responsive parkinsonism, non-fluent aphasia and corticobasal syndrome. As well as clinical symptoms, the degree of midbrain atrophy, a well-known imaging hallmark, is not consistent in pathologically proved atypical PSP patients. This fact has important implications for the limitation of midbrain atrophy as a diagnostic biomarker of PSP pathology. The purpose of this study is to review magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings of pathologically proved typical and atypical PSP patients for educational presentations of the imaging spectrum of PSP. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed conventional MRI mainly including T1-weighted, T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery images of 11 pathologically diagnosed PSP patients. Additionally, voxel based morphometry (VBM) analyses had been performed in six patients. Result: As expected, typical PSP patients revealed typical atrophy of the midbrain and superior cerebellar peduncle. Contrary to typical patients, other findings including the atrophy of the frontal lobe, cerebral peduncle and globus pallidus were more conspicuous in atypical cases. Notably, the atrophy of the left inferior frontal gyrus in a patient with non-fluent aphasia (PSP-PNFA) and asymmetrical paracentral white matter atrophy in a patient with corticobasal syndrome (PSP-CBS) were characteristic findings. On the other hand, a patient with pure akinesia with gait freezing (PSP-PAGF) revealed only mild atrophy of the globus pallidus. In addition to these atrophic changes, some patients revealed dilatation of the third and fourth ventricle and T2 prolongation of the globus pallidus and brainstem tegmentum. VBM analyses were useful for the objective evaluation of the subtle atrophy of the frontal lobe white matter and basal ganglia which were difficult for visual assessment. Conclusion: Radiologists should understand that in addition to the midbrain atrophy, PSP patients revealed the various imaging findings including abnormalities of the frontal lobe, globus pallidus and brainstem. Dipartimento Universitario di Scienze Biomediche Avanzate, Università degli Studi di Napoli Federico II, NAPOLI, ITALY, 2 Dip. di Neuroscienze, Scienze Riproduttive e Odontostomatologiche, Università degli Studi di Napoli Federico II, NAPOLI, ITALY Purpose: Middle ear cholesteatoma is an enlarging cystic keratin-filled mass surrounded by stratified squamous epithelium, whose diagnosis in mainly based on clinical suspicion. MRI and DWI technique are the first step in diagnostic assessment when high tissue specificity and sensitivity are required. On DWI cholesteatoma is hyperintense, in part because of a restricted water diffusion, in part because its content of keratin produces high signal intensity in the pathological area (T2-shine-through effect),as shown calculating ADC values. Aim of the study is to define a range of ADC values, within which the diagnosis of cholesteatoma is certain. Methods: From April 2011 to April 2015, we studied 76 patients (41 females; 35 men; mean age 38,9Y) with suspicion of unilateral cholesteatoma. Patients underwent preoperative MRI few days before first or second-look surgery; diagnosis was confirmed histologically. Protocol was approved by local Ethical Committee and written informed consent was previously obtained from all patients. MRI was performed on a 1.5TMR unit (Philips Intera, Philips Medical Systems, Netherlands) with an 8-channel head coil and consisted in conventional sequences and coronal MSH non-EPI DWI. For MSH-TSE DWI, cardiac gating was performed in order to limit artifacts due to heart pulse/blood flow. ADC maps were calculated by a 15years-experienced neuroradiologist by placing a ROI of 1cm2 in the central portion of the lesion. We considered the average of ADC values within the ROI. Statistical analysis was performed with the Ttest, comparing the average ADC value of histologically confirmed cases of cholesteatoma versus histologically identified inflammatory lesions. Result: In 55 cases, cholesteatoma was confirmed histologically. Average ADC value for cholesteatomas was 0.80x10_3mm2/s (range:0,41x10_3/ 1,17x10_3mm2/s), for inflammatory lesions was 1.9x10_3mm2/s (range:1,19x10_3/2,44x10_3mm2/s) with no overlapping values in the two groups. The difference between this two groups was statistically significant for p<0.01. No significant difference was found between primary and recurrent cholesteatomas.Conclusion: Mean ADC values in cholesteatomas are significantly lower compared to inflammatory lesions. Although we cannot rule out the possibility of ADC value overlap in larger series. Our findings suggest that calculation of ADC values from MSH-DWI non-EPI can assist in the diagnosis of cholesteatoma in case with questionable clinical and imaging findings. Piattella 1 , N. Upadhayay 1 , M. Bologna 2 , A. Suppa 2 , E. Sbardella 1 , F. Tona 1 , C. Giannì 1 , C. Colonnese 1-2 , A. Berardelli 1-2 , P. Pantano 1-2 Department of Neurology and Psychiatry, University Sapienza, Rome, ITALY, 2 IRCCS Neuromed, Pozzilli, ITALYPurpose: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) and cortico-basal syndrome (CBS) are atypical parkinsonisms, characterized by tau accumulation in both neurons and glial cells, with consequent neurodegeneration and disconnection between subcortical and cortical structures. Whereas thalamic damage has been demonstrated in both diseases, the degeneration of the superior cerebellar peduncle has been selectively reported in PSP. The aim of this work was to investigate the impact of the pathological changes on functional connectivity (FC) within the thalamic and cerebellar resting state networks (RSNs) in these two pathologies. Methods: We recruited 19 patients with probable PSP, 11 patients with propable CBS and 12 age-and gender-matched healthy subjects (HS). Functional MRI at rest was performed using a 3.0 Tesla scanner (Verio Siemens). Functional MRI data were processed by means of FSL (FMRIB's Software Library) tools; thalamus and dentate nucleus were used as seed regions to identify the thalamic and cerebellar RSN, respectively. The threshold for statistical significance was set at p<0.05 corrected for multiple comparisons. Result: Both PSP and CBS groups displayed lower FC than HS in both RSNs. No significant differences in the FC of the thalamic RSN were observed between the two patient groups. Conversely PSP patients displayed reduced FC with respect to CBS within the cerebellar RSN, mainly involving the anterior cingulate, SMA, primary motor cortex and prefrontal cortex, bilaterally.

Terada 1 Department of Radiology, Toho University Sakura Medical Center, Sakura, JAPAN Purpose: To examine whether measuring maximum thickness of hippocampus and diameter of inferior horn on routine coronal FLAIR and reconstructed coronal T1-weighted image is useful or not to evaluate relative Alzheimer's disease (AD)-specific gray matter atrophy, which was calculated with SPM8-DARTEL based software for diagnosing AD: voxel-based specific regional analysis system for Alzheimer's disease (VSRAD). Methods: We retrospectively reviewed 23 patients with clinically-diagnosed AD (age; 80.8±3.4, male: female; 6: 17, MMSE score; 19.3±3.8) who had undergone routine and 3D T1-weighted MRI for detailed examination of dementia from 2011 to 2013 in our hospital. As an adjunct of differential diagnosis of dementia, twenty-two out of 23 patients underwent 123I-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy, which revealed normal H/M ratio on early and delayed phases. Then, we measured maximum thickness of hippocampus and diameter of inferior horn, and calculated hippocampal atrophy ratio (HAR: maximum diameter of inferior horn divided by thickness of hippocampus) on coronal FLAIR and reconstructed coronal T1-weighted image, which were vertical to anterior commissure -posterior commissure line and contained right mammillary body. We also calculated Z score (value of ADspecific gray matter atrophy compared with normal database bundled with VSRAD) with 3D T1-weighted MRI and VSRAD as a gold standard and performed correlated analyses between HAR and Z score. Result: HAR on coronal FLAIR image was right; 0.97±0.37, left; 0.91 ±0.35, Z score on VSRAD was right; 2.12±1.33, left; 1.91±0.89, correlation coefficient was right; 0.60, left; 0.72, respectively. HAR on reconstructed coronal T1-weighted image was right; 1.10±0.43, left; 1.00 ±0.31, correlation coefficient was right; 0.77, left; 0.86, respectively. Conclusion: Measuring maximum thickness of hippocampus and diameter of inferior horn on routine coronal FLAIR and reconstructed coronal T1-weighted image is a convenient and useful method to evaluate relative AD-specific gray matter atrophy.dementia,VBM,VSRAD EPO:139 OPTIMIZED PIPELINE FOR RESTING-SATE FMRI PROCESSING -A DATA-DRIVEN IMPLEMENTATION L. TABREF128.text: magnetic resonance imaging,permeability,blood brain barrier EPO:142 CLINICAL VALUE OF MR SPECTROSCOPY: HOW OFTEN DOES MRS YIELD MORE INFORMATION THAN MRI? J Hellstrom 1 , R Romanos Zapata 1 , S Libard 2 , I Alafuzoff 2 , J Wikstrom 1 , F Ortiz-Nieto 1 , R Raininko 1 Uppsala University -Department of Radiology, Uppsala, SWEDEN, Uppsala University -Department of Pathology, Uppsala, SWEDEN Purpose: To evaluate the utility of MRS in a clinical setting.Methods: 208 examinations of clinical patients with a good quality MRS and a confirmed diagnosis (neuropathological in 50%) were reviewed. An experienced neuroradiologist, blinded to the definite diagnosis but having referrals and earlier radiological examinations available, interpreted the MR images and repeated the review with MRS included. The neuropathological specimens were reviewed by two neuropathologists. Both single voxel spectroscopy (SVS) and chemical shift imaging (CSI) were performed in 105 cases, only SVS or CSI in 54 and 49 cases, respectively. MRS parameters: 1.5 T, SVS: PRESS TR/TE 5000-6000/20-30 ms, CSI: TR/TE 1500-2500/135-144 ms. The SVS data was processed by LCModel and CSI data by the softwares of the imager manufacturers. The diagnoses on MRI and MRS were compared with the definite diagnoses. Clinical diagnoses were grouped into categories: non-neoplastic disease, low-grade tumor (WHO grade I-II), high-grade tumor (WHO grade III-IV). If the method yielded a correct and incorrect diagnostic category as alternatives, the outcome was considered indeterminate. MRI and MRS were also compared to see which of them gave more information to the clinician. The method was considered: 1. very beneficial stating the correct diagnostic group or location for a lesion when the other method did not, 2. beneficial ruling out suspected diseases or being more specific compared with the other method, 3. not beneficial containing the same level of information, 4. misleading containing less or non-correct information. Result: The confirmed diagnoses were: 70 non-neoplastic lesions, 43 low-grade tumors and 95 high-grade tumors. For MRI, the results were: 130 cases (62.5%) correct, 39 cases (19%) indeterminate, 39 cases (19%) incorrect. With added MRS, the results were: 134 cases (64%) correct, 23 cases (11%) indeterminate, 51 (25%) incorrect. Additional information from MRS was: very beneficial in 7 cases (3%), beneficial in 24 cases (12%), not beneficial in 141 cases (68%), misleading in 36 cases (17%).Conclusion: When MRS is performed for clinical indications (uncertain or insufficient information on MRI), addition of MRS does not improve the diagnostic accuracy.The comparisons were made between disease categories. In selected cases, MRS may be a valuable method. MRS,Brain,Comparative study EPO:143 HUMAN PAPILLOMAVIRUS STATUS IN OROHARYNGEAL SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA: QUANTITATIVE AND HISTOGRAM ANALYSIS OF PERFUSION AND DIFFUSION MRI PARAMETERS M Han 1 , S Y Kim 1 , J W Choi 1 Ajou University Medical Center, Suwon, SOUTH KOREAPurpose: To investigate the differences in perfusion parameters from dynamic contrast enhanced MR imaging (DCE-MRI) and ADC values from DWI according to the presence of biologically active human papillomavirus (HPV) in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) Methods: 24 patients with pathologically confirmed OPSCC and underwent pretreatment DCE-MRI and DWI were enrolled and analyzed in this retrospective study. The DCE-MR and diffusion images were post-processed by using commercially available software (nordicICE, NordicNEuroLab). Quantitative parameters (Ktrans, Kep, Ve, Vp, AUC60-area under the signal intensity-time curve at initial 60s) from DCE-MRI and ADC value from DWI were calculated within the manually placed ROI plotted around the main tumor on every image slice. Histogram parameters consisting of mean, median, 25th, 75th percentile value, skewness and kurtosis of DCE-MRI parameters and ADC values were compared between the HPV-positive andnegative groups using the Mann-Whitney U test.Result: 12 patients were HPV-positive (50.0%). Mean, median, 25th, 75th percentile value of Kep were significantly higher in HPV-positive group (p=0.006). Any other values, skewness or kurtosis of parameters were not significantly different between HPV-positive and -negative patients. Conclusion: Our preliminary evidence promise imaging parameters could reflect the tumor genetic and histologic features associated with HPV in OPSCC. oropharyngeal squamous cell ca,human papillomavirus,perfusion, diffusion parameter EPO:144 FEASIBILITY OF HIGH-RESOLUTION MR IMAGING FOR THE DIAGNOSIS OF POSTERIOR INFERIOR CEREBELLAR ARTERY DISSECTION M Han 1 , J S Lee 1 , S Y Kim 1 , J W Choi 1 Ajou University Medial Center, Suwon, SOUTH KOREA Purpose: To evaluate the feasibility of HR-MR imaging diagnosing posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) dissection and to find most useful imaging findings suggesting dissection Methods: We retrospectively reviewed 104 patients suspected of having arterial dissection involving posterior cerebral circulation and underwent HR-MR imaging between March 2012 and March 2015. 66 patients were diagnosed with arterial dissection involving posterior cerebral circulation and 16 patients among them (24.2%) were diagnosed with isolated PICA d i s s e c t i o n b y t h e c o n s e n s u s a m o n g n e u r o r a d i o l o g i s t s , neurointerventionist and neurologist after reviewing all clinical andparaclinical investigations available at hospital discharge (initial CT, MR, DSA images and etiologic work-ups) and follow up. Two neuroradiologists independently reviewed the HR-MR images of patients finally diagnosed as PICA dissection and looked for evidence of dissection (mural hematoma, dissection flap, outer diameter enlargement on T2WI) on each sequence of HR-MRI (PDWI, T2WI, T1WI and CE-T1WI). Interand intraobserver agreement for detecting evidence of dissection was estimated using the Cohen's kappa coefficient. Result: Dissection flaps were seen in all cases on T2WI (100%) and secondly detected on CE-T1WI (81.3%). Outer-diameter enlargement of the steno-occlusive lesions on angiography was detected in most of cases (81.3%). A mural hematoma was best detected on CE-T1WI (50.0%). The two reviewers showed substantial to almost perfect agreement for detecting dissection signs on every sequence (Cohen's kappa coefficient: 0.63~0.94) Conclusion: HR-MR imaging could be a useful and non-invasive diagnostic tool for PICA dissection and dissection flap with outer wall enlargement on T2WI is most confident sign for suggesting dissection.PICA dissection,High resolution MR EPO:145 NON-INVASIVE QUANTIFICATION OF BRAIN PERFUSION AND CEREBRAL HAEMODYNAMICS WITH QUASAR ARTERIAL SPIN LABELING (ASL) IN PATIENTS WITH CAROTID ATHEROSCLEROTIC STENOSIS C. TABREF129.text: BRAIN PERFUSION,CAROTID STENOSIS,ARTERIAL SPIN LABELING EPO:146 ASSESSMENT OF BRAIN TEMPERATURE AND WHITE MATTER DAMAGE IN SUBACUTE CARBON MONOXIDE POISONED PATIENTS USING DIFFUSION TENSOR IMAGING S. Fujiwara 1 , Y. Yoshioka 2 , T. Matsuda 3 , H. Nishimoto 1 , T. Murakami 1 , A. Ogawa 1 , K. Ogasawara 1 , T. Beppu 1,4

TABREF130.text: Methods: In thirteen CO-poisoned patients, DTI were performed on 3 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging system in the subacute phase after CO exposure. BT was estimated from MD value of corticospinal fluid measured in the segmented region of the subarachnoid space on a slice showing the centrum semiovale and it was calculated with T [°C] = 2256.74/ln[(4392.2×10-3)/MD]-273.15. WM damage was also assessed on the same slice using FA from the same DTI dataset. Normality distribution and correlation were examined by Shapiro-Wilk test and Pearson correlation coefficient with p<0.05. Result: MRI acquisition was successfully performed in all patients. Both BT and FA showed the normal distributions (p=0.2072 and 0.2736, respectively) and significant correlation was observed between BT and FA (r = 0.6483, p=0.0165). One of 13 patients showed delayed neuropsychiatric sequelae (DNS) on Day 27 after CO exposure, which is well-known that it shows deep CWM damage in the subacute phase and this patient showed the lowest BT and FA in all patients. It suggested that the brain metabolism in DNS patient might be reduced less than the other patients. Conclusion: BT and CWM damage estimated by DTI may help us to assess the brain metabolism in CO-poisoned patient.brain temperature,diffusion tensor imaging,carbon monoxide poisoning EPO:147 MRI ASSESSMENT OF VASCULAR CONTACT OF THE FACIAL NERVE IN THE ASYMPTOMATIC PATIENT G. Fletcher 1 , K. Nelson 1 , A. Patel 1 , J. Hoxworth 1 , N. Deep 2 , D. Barrs 2 Mayo Clinic Arizona, Dept of Radiology, Scottsdale, USA, 2 Mayo Clinic Arizona, Dept. of Otolaryngology, Scottsdale, USAPurpose: Vascular contact of the facial nerve is widely believed to be a cause of hemifacial spasm (HFS). The prevalence of facial nerve vascular contact on MRI in patients without HFS has not been well described in the literature. Methods: Our radiology data base was queried to identify adult patients evaluated with high-resolution MRI of the posterior fossa (volumetric T2 and T1 post-contrast sequences with triplanar reconstructions). Following exclusion of patients with a history of HFS, intracranial tumor, brain radiation therapy, intracranial surgery, or trigeminal nerve vascular compression, 100 consecutive MRI's (81 at 1.5 Tesla, 19 at 3 Tesla) were independently reviewed by two neuroradiologists for facial nerve vascular contact (200 sides). When vascular contact was identified, the facial nerve segment contacted was recorded (brainstem, root entry zone (REZ), or cisternal). When identifiable, the vessel responsible for the contact was recorded. Vascular contact was graded as mild, moderate or severe. Result: The cohort had a mean age of 55 years (range 22-89 years) and included 36 men and 64 women. The first neuroradiologist identified vascular contact in 83 of 200 facial nerves (41.5%). The segment contacted was brainstem in 23%, REZ in 32% and cisternal segment in 45%. Vascular contact was caused by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) in 13%, anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) in 69%, and a vein in 18%. Contact was mild in 83% and moderate in 17%. The second neuroradiologist identified vascular contact in 73 of 200 facial nerves (36.5%). The segment contacted was brainstem in 11%, REZ in 36% and cisternal segment in 53%. Vascular contact was caused by the vertebral artery in 1%, PICA in 9%, AICA in 60%, and a vein in 30%. Contact was mild in 77% and moderate in 23%. No cases of severe neurovascular compression were identified by either neuroradiologist. Conclusion: Vascular contact of the facial nerve is frequently identified in the asymptomatic patient, typically mild to moderate in severity, most commonly involves the cisternal segment, and usually caused by the AICA. These results should be considered in assessing the candidacy of HFS patients for microvascular decompression.EPO:148 MR MICRONEUROGRAPHY: A NON-INVASIVE TOOL FOR MORPHOMETRIC STUDY OF THE TIBIAL NERVE P. Felisaz 1 , F. Balducci 1 , S. Gitto 1 , S. Montagna 2 , G. Maugeri 1 , R. Vitale 1 , V. Busi 1 , A. Pichiecchio 3 , M. Baldi 2 , F. Calliada 1,4 , S. Bastianello 1,3 Radiology Department, University of Pavia, Pavia, ITALY, 2 Radiology Department, IRCCS Salvatore Maugeri Foundation, Pavia, ITALY, 3 Neuroradiology Department, C. Mondino National Neurological Institute, Pavia, ITALY, 4 Institute of Radiology, IRCCS Policlinico S. Matteo Foundation, Pavia, ITALYPurpose: To characterize and quantify the tibial nerve gross anatomy with an acquisition and segmentation protocol of Magnetic Resonance (MR) microneurography using 3D Spoiled Gradient Echo (SPGR) with IDEAL sequences. Methods: 14 healthy volunteers were investigated at the ankle level to obtain axial MR images of the posterior tibial nerve. Imaging was performed on a Discovery MR750 3T scanner (GE Healthcare, USA). Acquisition parameters: IDEAL 3D SPGR with TR 16 ms, TE 6 ms, flip angle 10°, matrix size 512 x 420, FOV 5 cm, slice thickness 2 mm for a coverage of 2.8cm, bandwidth 25 kHz, NEX 1, time scan approx. 7 min. The nerve was manually segmented by two experienced operators (PFF, SB) in the IN Phase image, where the nerve boundary was clearly visible. This region of interest (ROI) was used to mask the nerve in the water image, where 2 class segmentation was performed using FSL FAST 1. Fascicular volume (FV), epineurial volume (EV), nerve volume (NV), and fascicular to nerve volume ratio (FNR) were quantified in the 2.8 cm covered using partial volume estimation. Inter-observer agreement was computed using interclass correlation coefficient (ICC). Result: MR microneurograms demonstrated the various components of the nerve such as the external and internal epineurium, the nerve fascicles and even the perineurium. In the 2.8 cm covered, NV average was 276 mm3. The mean FV was 192 mm3 (range 124-251 mm3). The mean EV was 83 mm3 (range 52-137 mm3). The mean FNR was 0.69% (range 61-76%). The interobserver reliability was excellent for both FNR and NV (ICC of 0.975 and 0.967 respectively). Conclusion: Morphological detail usually achieved with conventional MR neurography is insufficient for automatic segmentation of nerve structure. We propose an acquisition and segmentation protocol for reliable quantification of peripheral nerve structural parameters thanks to the high resolution of MR microneurography. NVand FV may measure nerve and fascicular enlargement reflecting edema. EV may be correlated with intraepineurial adipose proliferation in chronic neuropathies. Despite of a limited coverage, our results are promising and suggest a possible role of MR microneurography in characterizing the spatial distribution and temporal evolution of peripheral nerve damage.MRI,Neurography,Microscopy EPO:149 FUNCTIONAL MAGNETIC RESONANCE IMAGING IN LATE LIFE DEPRESSION PATIENTS: A RESTING STATE STUDY F. Cieri 1 , R. Esposito 1 , N. Cera 1 , V. Pieramico 1 , A. Tartaro 1 , M. Di Giannantonio 1University G d'Annunzio Chieti-Pescara; Department of Neuroscience, Imaging and Clinical Sciences, Chieti, ITALY Purpose: Late life depression (LLD), occurs at age 65 or older, is estimated to affect 10% to 15% of the population. LLD patients have heterogeneous clinical features characterized by anhedonia, depressed mood, guilt and suicidal thoughts, in association with somatic complaints such as alteration of sleep-wake rhythm, loss or gain of weight, decreased libido and increased fatigue. Several studies have shown an association between depressive symptoms and Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). Previous studies showed modification of the Default Mode Network (DMN) and the Self-Referential Network (SRN). The aim of this study was to investigate the modifications of the intrinsic functional connectivity within resting state networks in LLD patients. Methods: After neuropsychological, neurological and psychiatric assessment, we study the resting state networks in 10 LLD patients (8 females; mean age 67,6±3,44 SD) and 1l healthy subjects (8 females; mean age 66 ±5,27 SD). Functional and structural MRI imaging was performed by means of a 3T Scanner. BOLD fMRI data were acquired in four runs lasting four minutes each by means of a T2*-weighted echo planar imaging (EPI) sequence with the following parameters: TE=35ms, matrix size 64 × 64, FOV 256 mm, voxel size 4 × 4 x 4 mm, 30 slices, TR=1671 ms. A high resolution structural volume was acquired via a 3D fast field echo T1-weighted sequence (matrix 256 × 256, voxel size 1x1x1, flip angle 12°, TR = 9.7 ms and TE = 4 ms). After preprocessing, data were analysed using the self-organizing group-level ICA algorithm implemented in BrainVoyager QX. Result: Among decomposed networks, between group differences were observed in leftFPN (Fronto Parietal Network)  and SMN (Somatomotor network). For left FPN, differences were observed in Dorso Lateral Prefrontal Cortex (dlPFC) and left Superior Parietal Lobule (SPL), whereas for SMN in Primary Somatosensory Cortex (p<0.05 FDR corrected). Conclusion: We hypothesize that the dysfunction in the FPN could explain the impaired cognitive control in LLD patients and some depressive symptoms. For the SMN alteration, we hypothesize that LLD patients could show a higher somatosensory perception to external environmental stimulation than healthy controls. FMRI,Late Life Depression,Resting State EPO:150 VISUAL LOSS AND VISUAL FIELD ABNORMALITIES: CHOOSE YOUR MRI PROTOCOL, REACH THE CORRECT DIAGNOSIS F. Dreyfus Heran 1 , F Lafitte 1 Fondation A de Rothschild Department of imaging, Paris, FRANCEAbnormalities of the papilla were best seen on FLAIR post gadolinium and on thin axial T2 WI Brain study helped to orientate the diagnosis. Multiple sclerosis, glaucoma, optic chiasm glioma, idiopathic intracranial hypertension were easy to diagnose. Sarcoidosis, inflammatory neuritis were either suggested by the brain abnormalities associated or by the evolution after steroid treatment. Ischemic lesions needed acute examination of the images. Sections of the optic nerve were best depicted with PDW sequence Conclusion: If MRI of the anterior optic pathway is easy to perform, essential protocol rules should be known by the radiologists to depict the various pathologies which may develop within or near optic nerves and optic chiasm. This work dramatically emphasizes MRI protocols, specific sequences and abnormalities features that help the neuroophtalmologists in the diagnostic procedure.Department of Internal and ExperimentalMedicine, Magrassi-Lanzara, Second University of Naples,, Naples, ITALY, 2 MRI Research Centre SUN-FISM, Neurological Institute for Diagnosis and Care Hermitage Capodimonte, Naples, ITALY, 3 Department of Medical, Surgical, Neurological, Metabolic and Aging Sciences, Second University of Naples, Naples, ITALY, 4 Neurology -CTO AORN Ospedale dei Colli, Naples, ITALY, 5 Department of Neuroscience, University of Parma, Parma, ITALY, 6 Department of Mental Health, Work Psychopathology Medical Centre, Naples, ITALY

TABREF132.text: DTI,TBSS,Multiple SclerosisEPO:153 ASSESSMENT OF WHITE MATTER MATURATION BY MEASUREMENT OF DIFFUSION-TENSOR IMAGING PARAMETERS USING AUTOMATED PARCELLATION METHOD S. Chang 1 , S. Chen 2 , D. Woolley 3 , M. DeBellis 3 , J. Provenzale 2,4 Eulji University Seoul Eulji Hospital -Department of Radiology, Seoul, SOUTH KOREA, 2 Duke University Medical Center -Department of Radiology, Durham, USA, 3 Duke University Medical Center -Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Durham, USA, Oncology and Biomedical Engineering, Emory University School of Medicine -Department of Radiology, Atlanta, USA Purpose: Diffusion-tensor imaging (DTI) values are usually used to evaluate white matter (WM) of brain maturation. Our purpose is to describe the automated parcellation method of region of interest (ROI) with the Large Deformation Diffeomorphic Metric Mapping (LDDMM) tool for measuring WM maturation in childhood and adolescence.Methods: Sixty-six healthy children (37 girls, 29 boys; mean age, 11.5 years; range, 4.2-17.7 years) underwent six-direction DTI with a 3-T MRI system. The images were processed using the MRIstudio software suite (www.mristudio.org, Johns Hopkins University; JHU) comprised of DtiStudio, DiffeoMap, and ROIeditor. First, DtiStudio was used to map fractional anisotropy (FA); apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC); axial diffusivity (AD); and radial diffusivity (RD). Second, ROIeditor was used to skull-strip of those maps. Third, DiffeoMap was used to spatial normalization of the skull-stripped maps. Fourth, those maps were used as our subject utilizing an atlas to subject linear transformation. Finally, LDDMM was utilized for the non-linear transformation. The resultant linear transformation matrix and the resultant LDDMM transformation matrix were applied to the WM Parcellation Map type II (WMPM II). The atlas-based analysis was completed using ROIeditor, so parcellation maps of total 130 ROIs were segmented. ROI statistics of four DTI maps were calculated as between 0.00 and 1.00 for 130 regions, then statistical analysis was performed to evaluate the data for some WM areas. Result: The corpus callosum were chosen for analysis. Increases in FA and AD values with age were noted, whereas high rate of decreases were noted in RD values. In most DTI studies, the importance of FA values in early life has been emphasized. However, a number of investigators have outlined the difficulties with accepting FA values as a measure of myelination.

TABREF133.text: Conclusion: The measurement of DTI values using automated parcellation method supports the contention that those are representative of different processes in the structural microenvironment.adolescence,diffusion-tensor imaging,radial diffusivityEPO:154 R E L I A B I L I T Y O F S E E D B A S E D F U N C T I O NA L CONNECTIVITY TECHNIQUE FOR FMRI DATA ANALYSIS IN AGING RELATED DISORDERS: NEW INSIGHT FROM INSULA N. Cera 1 , F. Cieri 1 , R. Esposito 1 , M. Di Giannantonio 1 , A. Tartaro 1Purpose: The seed-based functional connectivity(fc) during resting state fMRI(rsfMRI) has shown to be a reliable technique to study the temporal cross-correlations among cortical regions, which could be considered a good index of brain functioning. We aim to assess the reliability of seed based fc as a data analysis technique able to detect alterations of aging related disorders, such as Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and Late Life Depression (LLD), considering the subregions of the insula as seeds. Insulae are hidden by frontal and temporal opercula and play a key role in several functions and can be divided in subregions. The anterior and the posterior areas are related to distinct functional networks altered in neurological disorders.Methods: Participants: 26 adults (age: 25-35 years), 26 healthy elderly and 13 MCI and 10 LLD(age: 60-80 years) . RsfMRI data were collected with a 3T scanner : 3 runs T2*weighted:EPI, TE=35ms, matrix=64×64, FOV 256 mm, voxel size 4mm3, 140 volumes; T1: matrix=256×256, FOV 256 mm, voxel size 1mm3, flip angle 12°, TR = 9.7 ms and TE = 4 ms. After pre-processing and Talairach space normalization, 4 seeds were selected in 2 horizontal planes: left / righ anterior/ posterior insulae (aiLH, aiRH, piLH and piRH). Signals were z normalized and ortogonalized. To assess the reliability a between group comparison was performed . Result: Fc maps were calculated for the seeds and a voxel-wise ANOVA ( between-group factor = young, healthy elderly, MCI, LLD) was performed for each map. For aiLH, "healthy elderly>young" (p<0.05 FDR corr.) showed decreased fc in dACC , for aiRH (P<0.05 Bonferroni's corr.) decreased fc in dACC and for piLH decreased fc in putamen (P<0.05 Bonf. corr.). "MCI>healthy elderly"(p<0.05 FDR corr.) showed decreased fc for aiLH values in ACC and increased piRH fc values in theBA5. For aiLH 'LLD>healthy elderly" showed increased fc levels in left angular gyrus. "LLD>MCI" showed increased fc in the left angular gyrus(p<0.05 FDR corr.). Conclusion: Our results showed that seed based is reliable to detect alterations in pathological aging. We observed an increased fc in the LLD between the anterior insula and regions related to decision making, and internal state control.fMRI,Functional connectivity,Aging EPO:155 EVALUATION OF WHITE MATTER ABNORMALITY IN MILD COGNITIVE IMPAIRMENT USING DIFFUSION TENSOR IMAGING: A COMPARISON OF TRACT-BASED SPATIAL STATISTICS B. Cavusoglu 1 , E. Ada 2 , D.D. Emek Savas 1,3 , G.G. Yener 1,4,5 1 Department of Neuroscience, Dokuz Eylul University, IZMIR, TURKEY, 2 Department of Radiology, Dokuz Eylul University, Izmir, TURKEY, 3 Department of Psychology, Dokuz Eylul University, Izmir, TURKEY, 4 Department of Neurology, Dokuz Eylul University, Izmir, TURKEY, 5 Brain Dynamics Multidisciplinary Research Center, Dokuz Eylul University, Izmir, TURKEYPurpose: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia, and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is thought to be a transitional stage between normal aging and early dementia. Diffusion tensor imaging is an advanced magnetic resonance imaging technique that has been used to evaluate the integrity of white matter tracts in vivo. We aimed to evaluate white matter abnormalities on diffusion tensor imaging in patients with MCI, using Tract-Based Spatial Statistics (TBSS). Methods: 20 MCI patients and 20 age, gender and education matched healthy elderly subjects underwent diffusion tensor magnetic resonance imaging. A fractional anisotropy (FA) map was generated for each participant. Voxel-based group comparison statistics of fractional anisotropy was estimated using TBSS, which is provided in FSL software package. Result: TBSS showed that FA was significantly lower in MCI than in the healthy elderly group in the body and genu of corpus callosum, forceps minor, right inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, right anterior thalamic radiation, right superior longitudinal fasciculus, right cingulum and right superior corona radiata. Conclusion: TBSS is a useful method in examining the degeneration of white matter tracts and showed abnormalities in white matter in patients with MCI compared with healthy elderly group.Mild cognitive impairment,Diffusion tensor imaging,Tract-based spatial statisticsEPO:156 INTRAVOXEL INCOHERENT MOTION MAGNETIC R E S O N A N C E I M A G I N G I N T H E B R A I N T U M O R : TECHNICAL NOTESA Catanese 1 , D Casolino 2 , F Malacario 3 , C Zenesini 4 , F Toni 4 , L Cirillo 4 , R Agati 4 Department of Radiology -University of Bologna, Bologna, ITALY, 2 Olea Medical, La Ciotat, FRANCE, 3 Department of Radiology -University of Naples Federico II, Napoli, ITALY, 4 Department of Neuroradiology, IRCCS Institute of Neurological Sciences of Bologna -Bellaria Hospital, Bologna, ITALYPurpose: Intra Voxel Incoherent Motion (IVIM) is a potential noninvasive tool for diagnosis in brain tumours, still there aren't clear guidelines for its evaluation. In our study we compare IVIM with Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast MRI (DSC) in primary brain tumours stressing the issues found during the acquisition set-up and post processing step. Methods: Twenty-eight patients (mean age 56 years), part of them treated with chemo or radiotherapy, underwent MRI (3T, Sigma Excite GE) with 8 channel Phase-array HR coil. Spin echo echo-planar sequence (SE-EPI) with 13 b-values (0 -1.300 s/mm2) was used for DWI acquisition, while Gradient Echo echo-planar sequence (GRE-EPI) for DSC MRI. DWI was fitted with IVIM bi-exponential model to generate diffusion maps. For each lesion multiple regions of interest (ROI) were manually drawn and compared through IVIM and DSC maps.All the post processing evaluations have been done using Olea Sphere software (Olea Medical, La Ciotat, France), statistical analysis was performed with Real Statistic Resource Pack (Microsoft Excel 2010). Result: The computation of tissue perfusion fraction (f-IVIM) has been optimized for each ROI through several steps as motion correction, background suppression, thresholding (0<f-IVIM<0,3) and evaluation of fitting error. The correlation between f-IVIM and rCBV was checked with Pearson coefficient. We found good sensitivity (95,45%) and specificity(83,33%)  in characterization between high and low grade gliomas. On the other hand we experienced that necrotic, haemorrhagic and oedematous intra-tumoural areas as well as liquor affect deeply f-IVIM measurement. Conclusion: Cerebral tissue perfusion fraction (f-IVIM) quantification derived by IVIM analysis it's a new tool, non invasive compared to DSC MRI and potentially useful in gliomas grade discrimination but also in the chemo/radiotherapy follow-up evaluation. However it's necessary to know all the factors that can affect this technique and give feedback to software-house companies in order to improve the available tools for clinical purpose.E. Caverzasi 1,2 , N. Papinutto 1 , A. Castellano 3 , P. Scifo 3 , A. Bharatha 2 , M. Riva 4 , L. Bello 4 , A. Falini 1 , R.G. Henry 1,5

Left premotor lesions,fMRI,DTI EPO:159 A NEWAPPROACH IN NEUROIMAGING -GRASP SEQUENCE AT 1.5 T AND 3.0 T A Bink 1 , J Lieb 1 , T Schubert 1 , C Stippich 1 1 Division of Neuroradiology, University Hospital Basel, Basel, SWITZERLANDPurpose: Report on advantages with the new Golden-angle RAdial Sparse Parallel MRI sequence (GRASP) at 1.5 T and 3.0 T in patients with intracranial, head and neck diseases. The GRASP sequence combines the techniques of compressed sensing and parallel imaging for rapid continuous acquisition with the advantages of flexible spatiotemporal resolution using the golden-angle radial sampling scheme. Methods: The GRASP sequence was implemented on 4 MR scanners (Prisma, Skyra, Verio, Espree; Siemens Medical Solutions, Erlangen, Germany). Sequence parameters: TR/TE 4.42/2.13 msec, flip angle 12.0 degrees, slice thickness 2 mm, image matrix 256 x 256 mm, voxel size 2.0 x 1.1 x 1.1 mm, receiver bandwidth 400 Hz/voxel, 6/8 slice partial Fourier, temporal resolution 2.3 s, TA 4:02 min.

TABREF136.text: Arterial Spin Labelling,ASL,Perfusion EPO:161 NSSAFE STUDY: OBSERVATIONAL STUDY ON THE INCIDENCE OF NEPHROGENIC SYSTEMIC FIBROSIS (NSF) IN RENAL IMPAIRED PATIENTS FOLLOWING GADOTERIC ACID ADMINISTRATION D. Belsack 1 , J. De Mey 1 UZ Brussel -Department of Radiology, Brussel, BELGIUMPurpose: To prospectively estimate the incidence of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) after administration of gadoteric acid (DOTAREM®) in patients with moderate to severe renal impairment. Methods: A worldwide observational post-marketing study is being conducted to collect safety data of hundreds of patients with moderate to severe and end-stage renal impairment undergoing a routine contrast-enhanced Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) examination using gadoteric acid. At inclusion, status of renal function, risk factors, indications for MRI are recorded for each patient. Between 3 and 27 months after contrast-enhanced MRI, three follow-up visits are performed, separated by at least 3 months, in order to detect any occurrence of NSF. Result: As of February 10, 2015, the cut-off date for the interim safety analysis, the data of 512 patients (mean age: 69.5 years [range: 21-95]; male: 59.8%) were available for review. The mean eGFR was 37.3 ±15.9 ml/min/1.73m2 (range: 4.0-74.2) and the population included 68.4% of moderate, 16.2% of severe, 12.7% of end-stage renal insufficiency and 2.7% of kidney transplanted patients. Central Nervous System MRI examinations accounted for nearly 33%. To date, 288 patients attended the first follow-up visit (between 3 and 12 months after MRI), 176 patients attended the second follow-up visit (between 13 and 21 months after MRI) and 114 patients the third follow-up visit (between 22 and 27 months after MRI). Only 7 patients (1.4%) had serious adverse events but none of them were related to gadoteric acid.No cases of NSF were reported. Conclusion: This interim analysis of the NSsaFe study reports no cases of NSF in patients with moderate to severe renal impairment after the administration of gadoteric acid. nephrogenic systemic fibrosis,gadoteric acid,renal impairment EPO:162 A NOVEL AUTOMATIC METHOD FOR THE DETECTION OF MALFORMATIONS OF CORTICAL DEVELOPMENT BASED ON FRACTAL PROPERTIES OF CEREBRAL CORTEX F. Stulov 1 Bekhterev Psyhoneurological Unstitute, S-Petersburg, RUSSIAPurpose: The aim of our study was comparison of the hyppocampal volumes of healthy volunteers measured using FreeSurfer and DISPLAY postprocessing programs. Methods: 13 healthy volunteers ages from 28 to 51 years (mean age 41) were examined in the 1.5 T MRI scanner (Toshiba Exelart Vantage) using standard brain protocol plus isotropic MPRAGE (0.5 mm). For the postprocessing analysis we used automatic postprocessing program (FreeSurfer, Massachusetts General Hospital) and manual postprocessing program suitable for calculation in three orthogonal planes at the same moment (DISPLAY, Montreal Neurological Institute, Quebec, Canada). Hippocampal volumes were calculated manually by DISPLAY using method proposed by Malykhin N.,2006. Result: Mean volume of the right hippocampus was 3627±466 mm³ (DISPLAY), but 4300±479 mm³, (FreeSurfer), left hippocampus -3755±576 mm³ (DISPLAY), but 4386±476 mm³(FreeSurfer). So, the difference between two methods was 14.3-15.6%. Conclusion: This difference can be explained by the effect of partial volume, noises and other technical troubles of automatic postprocessing and accurate use of special 3-plane manual postprocessing data analysis. Methods: 17 patients (M:F; 5:12; age 21-65) from 705 hospital´s database patients with verified sarcoidosis who met clinical criteria for probable neurosarcoidosis were selected. 17 primary and 8 follow-up MRI were done using standardized protocol. back_matter.text: Neuroradiology Department, San Raffaele Scientific Institute, Milan, ITALY, 2 Neuroradiological Academic Unit, UCL Institute of Neurology, London, UNITED KINGDOM Purpose: The mechanisms of stroke in Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can be thrombo-embolic or haemodynamic, which may not be easy to distinguish in clinical practice. Our aim was to assess potential haemodynamic compromise in CAS, with quantification of cerebral blood flow (CBF) and arterial transit time (ATT) using QUASAR ASL . Methods: 22 patients with CAS enrolled in the ECST-2 (second European Carotid Endarterectomy Trial) with good quality baseline QUASAR ASL data. CAS severity was assessed on the basis of Contrast-Enhanced Magnetic Resonance Angiography. The vascular territories of Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA), Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA), Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA), Anterior and Posterior Border-Zones (ABZ, PBZ) were outlined on anatomical images, then transposed to measure CBF and ATT on corresponding maps. ABZ and PBZ angles were measured on functional ATT maps. Spearmann correlation, Kruskal-Wallis and Wilcoxon Signed Rank test were calculated (significant p-values<0.05). Result: Overall, the mean CBF of ACA, MCA, PCA territories was >40ml/min/100g, without significant inter-territorial differences; ACA Purpose: Optic nerve and optic chiasm are best imaged with MRI. The better the MRI protocol the best the result. We propose an overview of different abnormalities of the anterior optic pathways according to clinical data and selected sequences. Methods: Patients (adults and children) presenting with optic nerve and optic chiasm (AOP) impairment (visual loss, visual field alteration papilledema) underwent MRI examination. Among all the examination performed during the last 3 years, we selected those demonstrating abnormalities. MRI was performed on a Philips 3T ingenia. Patients were asked to keep their eyes shut. Protocol associated thin coronal T2 WI (2mm) and T1 post gadolinium FATSAT WI (3 mm ) focused on the AOP and brain 3D FLAIR and 3DT1 post gadolinium study. Complementary sequences such as diffusion, axial FATSAT T1 post gadolinium and T2 WI, PDW axial sequence, SWI or T2 GE, and MRA were added depending on the first images and clinical data. MRI were analyzed by two experts and abnormalities selected according to their shape, signal and location. Result: The most frequent AOP abnormalities described were HS T2, focal enhancement , atrophy, enhancement of the perioptic meningeal sheet. Dilatation of the perioptic CSF layer,compression of the nerve or the chiasm were more seldom. Rare hypertrophic optic chiasm was predominant on children. Purpose: Advanced diffusion MRI models such as Neurite Orientation Dispersion and Density Imaging (NODDI) have been recently developed to overcome DTI limitations. NODDI provides multiple compartmental fractions for a richer description of tissue microstructural properties. In this work we present the use of a single color-coded map to represent the information derived by NODDI. Methods: A two-shell NODDI protocol was implemented on 3T Siemens Skyra (30 directions at b=1000 s/mm2 and 60 directions at b=2000 s/mm2) and 3T Philips Achieva (35 directions at b=711 s/mm² and 60 directions at b=3000 s/mm²) and applied in several clinical contexts including demyelinating disease (i.e. multiple sclerosis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy), tumor (i.e. low-and high-grade gliomas, lymphomas), stroke and toxic/metabolic diseases (i.e. hyperosmolarity injury). Diffusion datasets were fitted to the NODDI model in MATLAB. NODDI decomposes the signal of a voxel in three-compartments: neurites, extra-neurite and isotropic Gaussian diffusion. We created a single RGB color-coded map of the three-compartment model (red for extra-neurite, green for neurites and blue for isotropic Gaussian diffusion), in which the relative contributions of the different microstructural compartments could be easily appreciated. Result: The NODDI color map provides a simple and effective way to visualize the relative weight of each compartment. In multiple sclerosis NODDI color map enables better visual assessment of the underlying microstructural changes in normal appearing white matter as well as within lesions. In brain tumors, the NODDI color map better illustrates the tumor extension and different components within apparently homogeneous lesions on FLAIR: cystic/necrotic and infiltrative tumor 1 Neuroimaging Lab, Scientific Institute IRCCS Eugenio Medea, Bosisio Parini, ITALY, 2 Functional Neurorehabilitation Unit, Scientific Institute IRCCS Eugenio Medea, Bosisio Parini, ITALY, 3 Child Psychopathology
